ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Small enough class that a virtual seminar is allowed.
Occasional group assignments/meetings outside of class with classmates and check-ins with the professor.
N/A
NA

Live seminar meetings, sometimes included guest lecturers (also live)
Small groups of students also met outside of class for a handful of assignments, this was always live and sometimes in person
None

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I strengthened my writing capability and better understood the elements that contribute to an effective essay.
This course helped me develop skills to improve my writing, tackle the drafting process more effectively, and learn how to successfully complete research.
Reflection skills, how to write concisely, different formats of writing, how to make the most of your introduction and conclusion
My writing through different strategies greatly improved.
I learned how to meticulously go through the writing process for a variety of papers including expository and research papers of differing lengths.

This class built up my writing skills as a whole: it helped not only improve my writing itself but also gave me useful strategies to help my writing going forward. The course also gave me the opportunity to participate in groupwork and practice virtual public speaking with opportunities to lead presentations and facilitate discussion among the class.
Got more comfortable with writing and learned a bunch of techniques.
I learned to focus on the editing process when writing formally in an academic setting.  I learned to use the writing resources provided at school.

Through our three units, I learned how to improve my close reading (mostly from passages, on one occasion also from a movie). I improved my argumentative writing, making my thesis better defended and my points more concise. I learned some really valuable strategies for editing papers that helped to improve the structure and cohesion of my papers. (Most of these argumentative strategies were applied to essays rather than spoken arguments etc)
I also learned about the many additional resources available as an undergrad: librarians, peer tutors, writing center etc that I can use in future writing courses

I developed strong argumentative writing by practicing what is called the "they say / I say" strategy to inform the motivation of the paper, peer-editing and revising essays from feedback, synthesizing many types of evidence, and more.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: The course was well organized and feedback on our drafts was a great strength of this course. Prof. Coleman was a great professor!

This course places a lot of emphasis on the drafting process in writing; consequently, you have a long time to complete each essay. This is incredibly helpful, and gives you a lot of time to utilize the new methods you're learning and to receive feedback on your drafts. There weren't any weaknesses.
Strengths: very engaging material and in class activities, very relevant to the topic of the course, explored a variety of styles of writing, all reading materials were very relevant
Some of the classes can seem monotonous but overall I think it was very helpful! These practices ultimately work.

Strengths - very strong sense of community and collaboration. I loved the discussions and methods used to improve the classes the writing in a seminar format. Great feedback and focus on personal growth as a writer.

There were not any weaknesses that stood out to me. Professor Coleman herself demonstrated how organized and balanced the course was: the way she facilitated class time contributed to a perfect combination of efficient learning, group discussion, and peer review. Another strength of the course was Professor Coleman's requirement of us to participate in using external resources like peer tutors and our personal librarians. These resources not only helped my work in the class, but also gave me comfort going forward throughout the course.
The professor gave great feedback and was really invested in our development as writers. The seminars were also well-planned.

The small class format would have been much more intimate and energizing if we had met in person, but online class was not the same (obviously out of control of Professor Coleman)
The pace of the class was perfect: plenty of time to work on papers but still with hard deadlines. The extra time to workshop/revise the papers in class with the help of classmates/instructor helped me to settle in to writing college papers.

Strengths: Professor Coleman focused on the development of each student as individual writers, pushing us to strive toward our respective writing goals continually. She gave great feedback. I thought the prompts for each paper made me think critically and were extremely fun to respond to.

Weaknesses: None

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This seminar succeeding in allowing students to engage with other students through participation.

The structure of the Zoom meetings were good and class was never stagnant. We all kept our mics muted when we weren't speaking, and when we went to speak we would unmute ourselves, which let everyone else know we were about to speak (to avoid those awkward moments of two people speaking at the same time.) Professor Coleman also utilized screen sharing regularly which allowed for a lot of engagement.
I think assigning us to groups outside of the class was very helpful. We actually got to talk to peers one on one and it helped build communities during a very stressful and difficult time.
The use of a daily schedules and slides readily available was super helpful and reliable.

This was by far my most engaged class: the seminar setting contributed to much of that, but Professor Coleman consistently made sure students had multiple ways to participate in both class-wide and breakout room activities and presentations, as well as encouraging students to participate in general .
All good.
Virtually meeting in small groups outside of class worked well, although there could have been more specific guidance as to what to do.

As I mentioned above, online class was not as energizing or enjoyable as in person. This was especially clear because it was a late afternoon class in New Haven so the in-person students (me at least) were not very awake/alert by then.
Success: This class felt like a small community. The breakout rooms helped facilitate peer reviews. Having our cameras on worked well because the format of the class was a seminar.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! This class allowed me to enhance my writing skills. I recommend this class to all students as it will be useful.

Yes! Taking this class is such a good way to improve your writing! There's so much help available that you never have to worry about just submitting an essay and getting a bad grade  you have plenty of time before each essay is due to get feedback on your drafts.

If you are okay with some exercises that might feel a little foolish at first, this class is great! My writing has actually improved greatly and there is no other class I know that allows you to truly focus this much on your writing in a productive way.

I would definitely recommend this course to freshmen at Yale because it's a good intro into college level writing without overloading you with work, and it also gets a writing distributional requirement out of the way. Plus, the topic of discussion was super interesting and allows for more self driven involement.

I would 100% recommend this course to another student. The class offers relevant discussion, stimulating ideas, a positive and constructive environment, and a great opportunity to build writing skills.
Yes, I felt that my writing ability improved quite a bit.
Yes. This course prepares me well with the tools to continue developing my writing on my own. I have a better sense of where my weaknesses are and how to improve them.

This class was not very demanding outside of class meetings but I still learned a ton from the time I spent reading and writing for it. It was a great course for a first year, definitely not too much busywork which I appreciated.
Definitely! Coming into this course, I didn't feel confident in my writing at all. However, Professor Coleman was amazing and helped me grow as a writer tremendously.
